p: Our bibliographical review process covered a total of 16 publications including three books [ 37– 39], and 13 scientific articles [ 32, 40– 51]. One reference accounted for 81.4% of the 495 ethnobotanical uses recorded [ 37]. In total, 416 plant species belonging to 110 families and 305 genera were documented through our literature search. The most represented families were Fabaceae (41 plant species, 9.9%), Asteraceae (37 plant species, 8.9%), Euphorbiaceae (24 plant species, 5.8%) ( Fig 1A). The most represented genera were Salix (9 plant species, 2.1%), Diospyros (7 plant species, 1.7%), and Acacia (6 plant species, 1.4%). One hundred seventy plant species were mentioned to be used as chewing sticks, 124 were used for periodontitis-like symptoms, 50 in cleaning gums, 32 for mouth sores, 25 for toothache, 17 for blackening/reddening, 13 as toothpaste, and 8 for halitosis. A total of 158 plant species were reported to be used in North America, 134 from Africa, 42 from India, and 22 from Japan ( Fig 1B).
